questions.text: A 30-year-old male was referred by his family physician due to angle closure glaucoma secondary to fairly deep peripheral anterior chamber. The exam finding is shown in the mage below. This phenomenon of angle closure is most often secondary to what primary underlying anatomic derangement.

options.label: C
options.text: Forward displacement of the ciliary processes

questions.correct_answer: C. Forward displacement of the ciliary processes
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Forward displacement of the ciliary processes Anterior displacement of the ciliary processes pushes the peripheral iris forward, which subsequently narrows the anterior chamber and blocks the trabecular meshwork . This has been confirmed with anterior segment ultrasonography . Patients who have plateau iris syndrome (e.g., are resistant to laser peripheral iridotomy) should be treated with long-term miotics and possibly iridoplasty. Plateau iris is a type of narrow angle more commonly seen in younger adults that can lead to chronic angle closure glaucoma. Plateau iris refers to the anatomical configuration of the iris.

Highyeild:

Plateau Iris Syndrome is a form of primary angle closure glaucoma caused by a large or anteriorly positioned ciliary body that leads to mechanical obstruction of the trabecular meshwork.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Plateau iris is caused by a narrowing of the anterior chamber angle due to insertion of the iris anteriorly on the ciliary body or displacement of the ciliary body anteriorly, which in turn alters the position of the peripheral iris in relation to the trabecular meshwork (i.e., placing them in apposition). Option: B. Plateau iris syndrome is defined as a persistently narrow angle capable of closure in spite of a patent iridotomy. Option: D. Plateau iris is an ocular condition that requires appropriate diagnosis and treatment in order to prevent vision loss. Early recognition and intervention are key components of a good overall prognosis in this patient population.

Extraedge:

Plateau iris configuration is characterized by an appositional angle with a flat iris configuration, in contrast to an anterior bowing of the iris seen in a “typical” angle closure glaucoma, in which there is a more crowded anterior chamber due to a hyperopic/short eye. Classically, with PIC, the iris configuration is planar and the depth of the anterior chamber is normal. questions.text: Figure 1. An elderly patient underwent an uncomplicated trabeculectomy of the right eye. The next day, the IOP was 1 mm Hg, and the patient had the slit-lamp appearance shown below. The bleb is flat. The retina and choroid appear normal. What is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bleb leak A low, often unrecordable IOP is common during the early postoperative period and is typically associated with a shallow anterior chamber . If there is an obvious hole in the conjunctiva, one would see brisk Seidel positivity and a flat bleb. Spontaneous closure of the defect is often possible with a pressure patch; however, if this technique is not effective, a Simmons scleral compression shell may help close the leak.

Highyeild:

Other treatment options for bleb leak include defect suturing , trichloroacetic acid, soft contact lens, and autologous blood injection.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Malignant glaucoma is associated with an elevated IOP and a flat anterior chamber . Option: B. Most serious choroidal detachments resolve spontaneously along with the normal rise in IOP during the first few postoperative days or weeks. In other cases, there may be no apparent conjunctival defect, but filtration may simply be excessive as a result of a large fistula or filtering bleb. Option: C. Fluid commonly collects in the suprachoroidal space in hypotonous eyes, leading to serous choroidal detachments. The fluid in the detachments is high in protein (67% of plasma concentration).

Extraedge:

Treatment Of Bleb Leak : Medical Treatment direct pressure patching bandage contact lens collagen shields compression sutures

questions.text: Various factors are responsible for the development of glaucomatous damage, with each factor being interlinked in its effects with all the others. Which of the following statements is true regarding this damage?

options.label: A
options.text: Direct damage of the optic nerve fibre bundles occurs due to significant forward displacement and compaction of the laminar plates.

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased perfusion pressure at the optic disc may be caused due to systemic factors like hypertension.

options.label: C
options.text: A raised intraocular pressure decreases axoplasmic flow in the initial stages.

options.label: D
options.text: Increased IOP may occur due to decrease the capillary blood flow due to decreased flow in the annulus of Zinn, which supplies nutrition to the prelaminar optic nerve head.

questions.correct_answer: C. A raised intraocular pressure decreases axoplasmic flow in the initial stages.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A raised intraocular pressure decreases axoplasmic flow in the initial stages. The pathogenesis of glaucomatous damage is attributed to a combination of factors affecting axonal health , with each factor being interlinked in its effects to all the others. The two main influences are as follows: Mechanical changes due to the rise of intraocular pressure Altered or decreased vascular perfusion of the optic nerve head

Highyeild:

A raised intraocular pressure causes mechanical pressure on the lamina cribrosa, altering capillary blood flow and decreasing axoplasmic flow in the initial stages.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. In the later stages of mechanical changes causing glaucomatous damage , significant backward displacement and compaction of the laminar plates narrow the openings through which the axons pass, directly damaging the nerve fibre bundles. Option: B. A fall in perfusion pressure at the optic disc may additionally be caused by systemic factors such as hypotension, vasospasm, and acute blood loss. Option: D. A substantial rise in intraocular pressure can also decrease the capillary blood flow due to mechanical compression of vessels at the lamina cribrosa or a decreased flow in the annulus of Zinn , which supplies nutrition to the laminar and post laminar optic nerve heads.

Extraedge:

Grading for glaucomatous damage are of three types; Mild Moderate Severe
